Title: My Opinion
Review:
Gosh, The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, I finally saw this film! Who hasn't heard of it? First off, may I say that Clint Eastwood... what a hottie in his day! :D Sorry, had to get that off my chest. Sergio Leone from what I understood was a huge western film fanatic and in the 60's pretty much most folks had moved onto other genre's. I mean, I would agree that most western's are pretty much the same and stereotypical.

Sergio however took a story and added some elements to it such as comedy, drama, and war. The story flows so well and just compliments all of it's characters. By far my favorite character was The Good, played by Clint. He is a bounty hunter who captures The Ugly numerous times just to free him before every hanging and splits the winnings with him. When they learn of a coffin in the desert that has $200,000, they go for it. Of course we have the Bad who is a ruthless killer who also wants in on the doe.

The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly is a terrific film and I thank all the IMDb users for their useful comments and that pushed me to finally rent this western classic. Let's give it up for Sergio!

Title: Sergio Leone
Review:
In 1964 Sergio Leone gave us the raw but impressive "A Fistful of Dollars", the next year he built on that with "For a Few Dollars More" giving us a glimpse of what was to come. And what was to come came in 1966 with what is widely claimed to be the greatest western ever made "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" or "Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo." to give it its original Italian title. A western of epic proportions and of epic length despite being shot on a very low budget. Not only is "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" such a great western but the directional style of Sergio Leone, used in all these three spaghetti westerns, have since influenced other directors most notably Quentin Tarrantino who you could say paid homage to Leone with his "Kill Bill" movies.

Title: Il Buono, Il Brutto, Il Cattivo
Review: You see, there are two types of people in this world; those who make Spaghetti Westerns, and Sergio Leone. Leone, the king of the Spaghetti Western, and one of the all time greatest filmmakers truly outdoes himself with his classic, 'The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly'. With this installment of the "Dollars" trilogy, during the Civil War, we find Blondie (Clint Eastwood), "the man with no name", in a not so morally sound partnership with an outlaw/bandit, Tuco (Eli Wallach). The two characters go from town to town performing a genius scheme that is Blondie catching Tuco and turning him in for money, and then setting him free the day of the execution. They split the reward and prosper, until one day Blondie ends the partnership, causing Tuco to begin a hunt for Blondie, until they cross paths with deadly bounty killer, Angel Eyes. Now its a three man witch hunt, and to make matters worse, they all get word of buried Union gold. Now a race for buried gold, and vengeance, is underway as the three men will do anything to prosper. With classic Leone intense close-ups, shootouts, and unique dialogue. 'The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly' is one for the ages, and will forever go down as one of the most phenomenal films in history.

Title: The essence of true film making
Review:
I may have seen this film about twenty times, but somehow this film never bores. For me this film encompasses the true art of film making, with simplistic scenes, sets, intriguing conversations and great music. From the opening scene where hit men gather in a deserted town, saying nothing, but express determination in fulfilling their objective, to the last duel where every tiny detail is filmed from eyes to fingertips. This in combination with greatly build sets (without CGI at the time) like a POW camp, a mysterious cemetery in the middle of nowhere, but above all the real naturalistic recordings at deserts and desert mountain areas. It really gives you the feeling of the real deal, outside Hollywood studies and that's what makes a spaghetti western great. You almost wish to be a cowboy yourself. Last (but not least) to mention the music, which perfectly fits the scenes and creates the extra dimension that makes this film a western masterpiece.

ENNIO MORRICONE the legendary italian westerns vol. two, a section of the liner notes reads: their first meeting yeilded more than it's share of surprises: "when he open the door, morricone looked at me and exclaimed "don't you know me ? we went to school together!" riminised leone "at first,i thought he was joking, but he proceeded to go into another room and returned with an old picture. sure enough: there we were, the two of us, seated next to each other in grammer school. i had forgoten all about it but he was right..."(the cosmic joker ?)

in american movies the score is always put in after the shoot. leone wouldn't dream of any shooting of a scene untill he first heard what morocone had composed first, which gave the director the vision needed to produce what should happen in the next scene. so it's this ultra-violent western captured by a dreamer(leone). the stuff revolutions are made of. meanwhile during fist full of dollars eastwood has whittled his dialogue to as few words as possible, thus helping create the man with no name image. the talking is done by tuco, benidicto, pacifico, ....juan, remerez/walach. every trick. cenimatic & musically, of first 2 pictures comes together. the musical pocket watch theme from for a "few dollars more" is inserted once more to increase the tension @ sadhill sequence. everytime i know this movie will be shown on t.v. Eli Wallach would've gotten Best Supporting Actor. Lee Van Cleef would've gotten a Best Supporting Actor nomination. Sergio Leone, Best Director. Screenplay, cinematography, musical score, the list goes on. It's not only the definitive western, but it has several other elements and plot lines. It's also a drama, a suspense film, a war film, an action flick, and a treasure hunt movie. With no details, it also has the greatest ending to a film ever put on screen. But everything about this movie is what makes it an all-time classic. Especially the reason it could never be successfully remade. The acting, screenwriting, directing, camera work, and brilliant musical score by Ennio Morricone are what make it unique to the point it can never be duplicated or improved. It isn't my favorite movie, but I tell everyone and anyone that this is the best movie ever made. I only believe that because everything in the movie holds its own and backs it up, and I hope anyone who watches it believes the same.

Title: If you never watched this film because you thought it looked boring...
Review:
Then, respectively, You Sir or Madam are a fool. Badly dubbed, sillily cast and horribly underloved, this is possibly the greatest caper of its time and ever since. In a time of Hollywood heroes, horrifying villains and not many people in between, Leone submits one of his many masterpieces to exhibition, at a time when America had given up on the western because it had nowhere else to go. This film offers no heroes, gives you a villain and places a slimy little dog like tuco into the midst of the most realistic portrayal of the west the way it was. Sad, lonely and most certainly devoid of John Ford colour. Ironic really that one of the most loved westerns of all time was made in Europe. Good job really, though. The Americans never could get their history right. Clint has never been so squinty, Wallach so perfectly cast and Leone so frankly plain. Film fans, this is a must see. But if you are a casual viewer you may want to steer clear, for only a tide of angry rebuttal awaits your confusion and refutation on the web.

Title: Morricone's Music
Review:
I have long been a fan of this movie and although I think the compelling nature of the story might suffer after multiple viewings, I think the artistic aspect endures. Leone "paints" his scenes in some sense. And that amazing scenery - the desert and the clear blue sky. And Leone must have been such a civil war buff to be talking about Andersonville and all that. But I have one question for this movie's fans with which they might be able to help me - that tune the confederate orchestra is playing while Tuco is having the stuffing beaten out of him by the big thug working for Angel Eyes - is that a creation of Morricone or is it an adaptation of some civil war ballad that dates from the historical time of the action? I find it a very haunting melody. In some ways the music, plus the cinematography makes this film. And before I go, what about Eli Wallach? Clint has always been Clint at some level but Eli's versatility is evident if one compares his role as Tuco to the many other things he has done over the years. So there are two kinds of people in this world - those who dig the best elements of Leone and those who just say "It's another Western." - Yours Truly, Blondie Ramirez.

Title: In this review, I discuss the film's music.
Review:
The Effects of the Music in the Film The Good the Bad and the Ugly by Brian Coatney

The Good the Bad and the Ugly made its indelible imprint in 1966 as the third of the Spaghetti Western trilogy, and it remains a piece of cultural lore even today for its inimitable synchronization of music and acting that produce dramatic tension neither the music or acting alone could generate. With a script that violently veers from traditional Western themes, Sergio Leone's artistic classic changed American culture as much as Woodstock did. Only a book could detail all the interesting aspects of the film, but here, I will comment on the music. Music is universal and sometimes music strikes us in a way we're not even conscious of, and it draws us with a power and mystique we can't yet identify and probably don't give that much thought to at first. Don't we often respond first by liking or disliking something before we know how to analyze why? So it was with the music in the Good the Bad and the Ugly. All I knew was that the music created an alluring mood in a mysterious and enticing way, giving the sense of what film critic Bill Warren calls an "astonishing score." The music is, in fact, exceedingly more than mere background or accompaniment to the film's action; its "lonely, mournful scores are inseparable from the film" (Ebert). Critic Vince Leo says that Morricone's score enabled the film to go from "good film to masterpiece." Not only that, "Unlike most films, where the composer would create the music based on what happens on the screen, it is said that Leone worked the opposite way, constructing scenes to fit the pieces of music" (Leo). One might say that with The Good the Bad and the Ugly, we enjoy a film made for its soundtrack rather than a soundtrack made for a film. If asked to describe the music of the film without reference to research, I would have described it like this: full of melody, a whistle pipe sound, rattle snake clicking at times, escalating tension on some kind of stringed instrument, slightly orchestral sounds, choral–like chanting voices, dramatic and paced buildup of tension—all of which was not overpowered with bass, rhythm, and vocals, meaning therefore not a band trying to create a full sound at high amperage. Somehow the music linked to the action, or shall I say non-action; for the music came into presence most it seemed when the characters stopped, spoke little, and hovered on the verge of a new twist in the drama: someone was about to draw, see an ominous presence, or experience an encounter of deep pathos and random violence—violence random to the victim but part of the consuming scheme of getting the gold buried in the graveyard somewhere. The famous signature score for the film came to signify in popular culture, a dramatic moment with peril in the air, a kind of pop icon score tied to antiheroes and subjugation of one person's dreams to those of another. A look at the critics fills in the detail that clarifies exactly what Morricone did. Max Garrone calls the film "balletic violence," with its "grand arias of whoops, whistles, Jew's-harps, gunshots and other errata." Also, we learn that the sound comes from a "blend of guitars, drums, and hyena-like cries from the singers" (Leo). Getting more precise, Warren points out that Morrricone, "blends elements of Mexican mariachi music with contemporary jazz, sweeping orchestral passages, choral voices, and an overall vividly distinctive approach." The music so much penetrates the film that it "incorporates the howl of a coyote—the first thing we hear in the movie itself—into the themes he creates for each title character, though the wail is orchestrated very differently each time" (Warren). Director, Serge Leone, then must mean for us to hear the coyote's pathos in each character, whether good, bad, or ugly—a wail that gives us the prime musical elixir that penetrates and binds together the film's tone of deep pathos.

Works Cited

Ebert, Roger. "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly." Rogerebert.com. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.

Garrone, Max. "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly." Salon.com. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.

Leo, Vince."The Good, The Bad and the Ugly (1966) / Western-Action aka Il Buono, Il Bruto, Il Cattivo." Quipster's Movie Reviews. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.

Warren, Bill. DVD Reviews. "The Good the Bad and the Ugly." audio video REVOLUTION. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.

Title: Heading for Number One !
Review:
Hi, all you commentators !

It's great to know that there are many many people around the world who look at this film as I do, -Numero Uno.

Since my last Comment (June 2003), I have now got the full Directors cut, complete with the deleted scenes back in. At the time, I commented that it should be technically fairly easy to "splice" these back in and have people to voice over the original Italian dialogue.

But then hey, what happens, ! They've gone and done the best possible thing, hired Clint Eastwood and Eli Wallach to voice over their own original dialogue (plus another to double on Lee Van Cleef)- Almost forty years later !.

This totally revamped film with its replaced scenes makes it a whole new thrill to watch. If you haven't got it, then get it pronto!

I have no doubt that with the passage of time, The Good, The Bad and the Ugly will become certainly the greatest western ever made and possibly one of the top films of all time.

See you soon, idiots !

Title: The reason why I started working in film.
Review:
I don't want to lose too many words to this movie, as it speaks for itself. Although being one of the most influential and important Western films of all time, I have a very special connection to this film.

Back when I was a child of 10 years, "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" was one of the first rated movie my father ever showed to me - although not being anywhere near the advised age. It didn't matter anyway, as I was deeply touched by the movie back then. It was its visuals, the incredibly well shaped characters (main and support) and the unforgettable and everlasting mega-score of the old master, Ennio Morricone. Grown up to a father, both Italian and a producer, film and especially Italian film was always a topic and a passion that made up a huge part in our family life. Still, I've never seen my father more emotional and feverishly romanticising about a movie as he did it with that one.

Nowadays, having seen this beauty for so many times that I lost count, I honestly recognise something new with every new session. It doesn't really matter if you focus on the unbeliveably well visualised portrayal of social contrasts in the past US, or the break with the glorification of classical American Western movies - this film was and still is revolutionary for its time and a predecessor for all the great Western, and other films in other genres, you can watch and enjoy today.

I fell in love with this movie when I was 10 and I still get the same feeling every time I rewatch this beauty.

10 out of 10 (and not just because of the age...)

Title: Excellent Story and Excellent Direction
Review: One of the finest films made in recent years. It's a poignant story about hope. Hope gets me. That's what makes a film like this more than a movie. It tells a lesson about life. Those are the films people talk about 50 or even 100 years from you. It's also a story for freedom. Freedom from isolation, from rule, from bigotry and hate. Eli Wallach, Lee Van Cleef, Clint Eastwood are majestic in their performances. Each learns from the other. Their relationship is strong and you feel that from the first moment they make contact with one another. There is also a wonderful direction from legend Sergio Leone as well. This film probably had the largest impact on my life. It set the tone for everything I then got interested in. American Civil War. Film Music. Clint Eastwood. Real Westerns. This is the best of the Dollars Trilogy and by far one of the best Westerns of all time. It has drama, comedy, cracking dialog, some of the most brutal battle scenes - especially around the bridge - that I'd seen up to then, music to die for and set pieces that just ooze atmosphere and tension. I have never forgotten the end shoot-out. It was just simply incredible.

Title: Timeless Classic
Review:
Having watched this film originally in the early 70's it was easy to distinguish this as a serious attempt at a spaghetti Western unlike the comical Trinity movies with Henry Fonda. There are so many scenes that are interwoven masterfully with one of the best musical scores from legend Morricone. The cassette tape of the score made excellent driving music in its time. I did see this in Italy in the 80's where it has always been intermittently screened since its original release but was a tad disappointed at the condition of the print. The new double disc DVD finally does this film justice as it blows up well in a big screen HT. They added stereo to the mono soundtrack and even managed to tune up the picture quality a bit from the previous anamorphic DVD. (If only they would enhance the other 2 films in Sergio's trilogy).

If you have never seen this but have seen Fistful of Dollars or For a Few Dollars More, you will realize that Eli Wallach is a key reason for the added enjoyment Leone's fans realize with this film. Tuco is what makes this movie. He is the semi-bad guy you grow a soft spot for, especially in repeat viewings. His acting and facial expressions throughout and especially through the tense final moments of the film are almost without equal. I applaud Wallach who to this day is an active actor working in films (Mystic River) as he enters into his 90's.

For some of today's youth who may be used to fast pace plots filled with endless stunts in a 100 min movie, all I can say is be patient sit back and enjoy.

Title: Cinematic Genius
Review:
I love this film. Every aspect; the characters, the story, the music. My favorite movie. The Trio is the greatest scene in the history of movies. Some fools scoff that it's boring. Boring? Have you never heard of suspense. Morricone's score gave me goosebumps.

Leone is a genius of a director, RIP. Clint Eastwood is good in anything he does. This is his best western, and certainly my favorite. It almost transcends being a movie, it's so fantastic. Leone's spirit still lives on. Enough cannot be said about this film and it's greatness.

11 stars A masterpiece.

Title: The other West
Review: I first watched Leone's trilogy when i was 12 years old. For the past 10 years, i have remained faithful and watched them at least once a month. One word could sum up this director's work: masterpiece. The very simplicity of the sceneries and the scenario, the chasteness of the characters, the alternative view on the West, even the minor faults in the shootings represent the reasons why Leone's movies are still the benchmark of all westerns. In this last film of the trilogy, the masterpiece concludes by portraying an image of the Far West that American western directors could've never even dreamt of. The pursuit for gold, the atrocities of the Civil War, human vices, all brilliantly presented by Leone. And all the above come in a movie that has no room for fresh, clean, crispy shirts that characters in various other westerns wear; And no, the sheriff is not a brave hero that shoots the bad Indians but only a man trying to make a living, the cities in Far West are not full of posh-ladies and righteous people, and above all when people get shot at surprisingly they get hurt! The picture of the West althoug not a rosy, happy one still is as real as it gets. And by featuring one of the coolest picture characters (Eastwood), a bad character whose just the voice gives u the creeps (Cliff), and one of the funniest characters ever to appear on a western (Tuco), this movie resembles perfection in its kind.

Title: this movie is under rated
Review:
This movie is terribly under rated. This movie seems to have almost everything. Leone makes it so that we feel such compassion for his characters. One of the best parts of the films may be when Tuco is talking to his brother and when he's talking to Blondie about the great relationship he has with his brother, the priest. This movie is set on an epic scale and Leone steps up to the challenge of directing what Tarantino calls the 'best movie ever directed.' The opening sequence of credits may be the best I've ever seen. Setting the characters' faces in a monochromatic style while playing Ennio's main theme song for the movie was great. Perhaps this movie is under rated because Westerns haven't enjoyed the same prestige as other genres. It is true that most Westerns are usually drawn out, but Leone is able to keep with that sluggish pace and long running time, while keeping the audience excited and anxious for more. This movie is more than the greatest Western of all time, it is THE BEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME!!! 'If only I had time to tell you.'

Title: Brilliant.
Review:
This is the last in the "Man With No Name" trilogy, directed by Sergio Leone and starring Clint Eastwood, and is, without a doubt in my mind, the very best. This includes not only in the trilogy itself, but also every Western I've seen thus far. Both a commentary on war and an adventure story, The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly is about a hit-man called "Angel Eyes"(Lee Van Cleef), a bandit named Tuco(Eli Wallach), and the Man With No Name(Clint Eastwood), who go to find gold hidden by a soldier during the American Civil War. The movie has some of the best directing I've seen in a movie and has some great music to go along with it.

Bottom line: If you are a fan of Westerns(or hey, even if you aren't), see this film.

Title: Where life has no value, death, sometimes has its price
Review:
The wild untamed west, the quickness of the draw, the thundering of hooves, the stylish lighting of the cigar, the ruggedness of the landscape, the matching intensity of the characters...all captured beautifully in this gripping trilogy of "Fistful of dollars", "For a few dollars more" and "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly".

Based on the life of a bounty hunter, "the man with no name", played superbly by Clint Eastwood, the series takes us through his eventful journey, one that is in search of lucre, and one, which, alike all such journeys, has no end. The character of mwnm (short) leaves one in amazement at the beautiful shades of grey that Hollywood paints its characters in. On one end, the hard, ruthless killer, the fastest hand in the west, stopping at nothing to get his bounty and on the other, the tender caring humanitarian, uniting a mother forced into prostitution, with her husband and child, saving a man who stood by him, giving a dying soldier his last smoke. Eastwood excels in an underplayed role, mixing quiet aggression with an angelic demeanor; a potent combination, which any hit-man today would kill for.

Ably supported by an array of Mexican acting talent and the likes of Lee Van Cliff and Eli Wallah, this trilogy, transports you to a world, where people wore their heart on their sleeves, had a contempt for their own lives and for that of others, a world where surviving each passing day was as challenging as moving from one dusty town to another, as though one were moving from one battlefield to the next. The savagery of the wild west is given a sublime touch by the hauntingly soulful soundtrack; the musical mastery of Enrico Morricone. Kudos Amigo! And to borrow a line from Tuco, "The Ugly" one, "There are two kinds of people in this world my friend, those who have seen this masterpiece and those who have not".

Title: A Masterclass in Filmmaking
Review: My favorite movie of all time is The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly. Most critics and audiences tend to agree that this movie is exceptional. It's had a continued impact on the way films are made. And even over 50 years after its release, it has been able to entertain and influence a Gen-Z kid like me. What makes this amazing? There are so many things. I love treasure hunting, I love westerns, and I love the civil war, and the plot manages to seamlessly create a perfect story. The three titular characters are all interesting and beg for your attention from beginning to end. Blondie is a mysterious hero with a cowboy's charisma. He's just so cool that you have to root for him. Tuco delivers comic relief perfectly and his constant change of allegiance keeps me guessing. And finally, Angel Eyes is an impeccable antagonist; a dark, enigmatic hitman who's willing to do anything to get his prize. The three are portrayed perfectly by Clint Eastwood, Eli Wallach, and Lee Van Cleef. These are all dynamite performances, and it behooves any actor to study them. The gritty and violent western vibe is heightened in intensity by the backdrop of the civil war, giving it historical significance and a great background for the main characters to interact with. And let's not forget the music. This movie also has my favorite film score of all time. Ennio Morricone delivers impeccable music. It's soft and reflective when it needs to be, and it's epic and dramatic when the action builds up. Overall, I could go on and on about why The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly takes the crown for my favorite movie, but I think the movie speaks for itself. When I first saw it in 2014, I was struck. I was in awe. I was completely satisfied. There's absolutely no problem with it that I can name. There are a lot of great westerns, but Sergio Leone's masterpiece stands out because it uses so many interesting elements, and converts them into a realistic and impeccable story that I could never forget. A remarkable achievement in film history and art history, The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly is rightfully my favorite movie of all time.

Title: Stolid, gripping, Masterful and realistic Western
Review:
Directed by the legendary Sergio Leone and music by the Masterful Ennio Morricone, Good Bad Ugly is bound to be a classic. On top of that, Clint Eastwood's charisma, Eli Wallach's ruthlessness and Lee Van Cleef's cold bloodedness pack quite a punch. Set in the civil war era, in some unnamed frontier town in California (a guess), it's a story of 3 gunmen. How they fight through a bounty huntings, sheriffs, war torn towns and seedy bars to get their ultimate prize, a bag worth 200,000$ gold belonging to a former Confederate General. Contains realistic shooting scenes, emotional wallops and a gritty display of frontier life. A Must watch for people who like all male, slow paced westerns. A warning, it's quite long, so pack 3 hrs well before hand.

Title: There's no name on this rock either...
Review:
In a movie that consists of only quotable quotes, Eli Wallach's character Tuco has the best lines. Clint Eastwood rarely talks and Lee Van Cleef is menacing but honorable at the same time.

Why is this movie so good? Frankly, I have no clue. From a technical standpoint, the pacing is awful. The movie runs for 3 hours, which is much too long for what its plot is. Much of the screen time is dedicated to a staring contest between participants in a gunfight.

My best guess as to why this movie resonates so deeply with all of us is because of the lack of a good guy. All three of the characters are not very nice. There is no sheriff to dull the action. But they all have a good side. Lee Van Cleef's is the hardest to see. In fact the only good one can even see in him is the fact that he doesn't kill certain characters when he has a chance to such as Bill Carson's whore or Blondie. But somehow Leone extends this (or maybe its just me)... I just don't see Angel Eyes as completely bad.

Blondie and Tuco have a strange love/hate relationship. We can all relate to their friendship. They're only friends when it benefits them... or are they? Blondie's actions at the end suggest that maybe the Man with No Name actually cares.

And the famous final gunfight. Its been emulated so many times, but never matched. God its perfect cinema. Never have I seen such a tense moment in the history of film. I will never forget the first time I saw the film and the gunfight. I was drawn in instantly.

But my favorite parts of the film are the little touching side stories and add-ins that Leone gives. The legless desperado who receives money for the information he provides and then wastes his money on liquor; the scene in the monastery with Tuco and his brother; the drunken general; and the dying Confederate soldier at the end... these scenes are what give The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly the kind of beauty that lacks in so many other western copycats.

Sure Blondie is one cool guy who pretends that he doesn't have a heart. But when he finally reaches his catharsis... when he finally admits how much the war is "a waste of men"... we realize that Blondie does have a heart -- he just hides it.

Why? Maybe because it hurts too much to show it. A Fistful of Dollars suggests that (Although Leone never intended for the dollars movies to be connected). If you haven't seen this movie, you are missing out on a landmark Italian movie. After watching this, I was hooked on Italian film. I started watching all of Leone, Fellini, Argento... Italian films are full of life that American films lack-- there's some sort of strange mystical wonderful culture in them that I just love. Watch this.
